title: Cat. 10  Young Peasant Having Her Coffee, 1881
publication_title: Pissarro Paintings and Works on Paper at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Young Peasant Having Her Coffee  
1881  
Oil on canvas; 65 × 54.5 cm (25 5/8 × 21 7/16 in.)  
Signed and dated: C. Pissarro / 1881 (upper right, in white paint with some red)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Potter Palmer Collection, 1922.433

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">After a rather long hiatus from figurative work, Pissarro began to make paintings of family members and local rural workers again in 1872 but stopped the practice after five years. It was not until 1879 that he resumed this practice, and it is fair to say that during the ensuing two years, for the first and last time in his career, his canvases were dominated not by landscapes but by people. These works were first shown at the fifth Impressionist exhibition in 1880, represented by a single large picture and two smaller works: Woman Scraping a Pot (1879 [PDRS 590]), Father Melon Sawing Wood (1879 [PDRS 610]), and Young Girl Carding Wool (1880 [PDRS 628]).

Pissarro’s renewed interest was in full force by the seventh Impressionist exhibition of 1882, which featured at least sixteen of his figure paintings, including the present work, which was listed as number 111 in the manuscript for the catalogue under what remains its title: Jeune paysanne prenant son café (Young Peasant Having Her Coffee). Pissarro’s figural paintings were prominent enough in the context of the exhibition that four of them were caricatured by the satirical magazine Le Charivari in an article titled “Une visite aux impressionnistes” (A Visit with the Impressionists), along with seventeen other works by him, Gustave Caillebotte, Claude Monet, and Pierre-Auguste Renoir (see fig. 10.1, fig. 10.2, fig. 10.3, fig. 10.4 [PDRS 640], and fig. 10.5). Here, the work is given the punning title Le café au laid (laid, which means “ugly”, sounds like the French word for milk, lait). The size of the girl’s cup (see fig. 10.6) makes it clear she is drinking café au lait, as this beverage is typically served in large round mugs.

The painting had already sold to Paul Durand-Ruel, Pissarro’s dealer, before the exhibition, on December 19, 1881, which indicates he must have completed it by that date. In fact, all the paintings by Pissarro in the 1882 exhibition were already owned by Durand-Ruel, who had purchased most of them in 1881. Young Peasant Having Her Coffee was among the most critically well received of the group. It was specifically mentioned in many reviews of the 1882 exhibition, and several other critics—including some of the most prominent—did not mention it by name but did discuss Pissarro’s figure paintings with real enthusiasm.

The general comments about the artist’s figurative work are worth exploring because they reveal a fundamentally sympathetic reaction to these experimental pictures—and also some stubborn patterns of comparison, particularly with Jean-François Millet’s work, that likely disturbed the artist. For example, in his review in La revue politique et littéraire, Charles Bigot remarked, “Here is Pissarro, who never tires of being a landscapist but has undertaken the feat of competing with Millet’s peasants. There is no doubt that his peasants recall Millet’s but what good will this do for him, when this memento will only manage to erase his own?” The opinion of other reviewers of the seventh Impressionist exhibition was split down the middle. They either recognized Pissarro’s innovative and fresh depiction of rural peasants—and thus his ultimate departure from Millet’s style—or refused to acknowledge the Impressionist’s skill without referencing his predecessor.

Some critics, however, avoided comparisons to Millet and chose to discuss Pissarro’s unusual technique instead. In Le français C. André noted, “I will say the same about Pissaro [sic], who, along with Vignon, has the most qualities among these artists, but whose complex execution ruins those very same qualities. Mr. Pissaro [sic] has invented what I would call relief painting. His works resemble topographical maps, with peaks and valleys. At the same time, however, his rural scenes have a certain naive charm, and if the painter just abandoned his manner of execution, he would immediately be given the credit he deserves.” André’s comments recognize the artist’s desire to make his figures breathe with life not by manipulating the subject but through his handling of color: a formal concern shared by most, if not all, of the Impressionists.

In Le pays Paul de Charry focused on Pissarro’s portrayals of peasants, partly echoing André’s ideas: “An artist with real talent as a draughtsman is Mr. Pisaro [sic]. The poses of his figures are truly natural and alive; one gets a real sense of movement and life breathing through his market women, dressed in vibrant colors and blending in nicely with the dusty, sun-filtered glow.” By contrast, Émile Hennequin, in La revue littéraire et artistique, identifed what he perceived as shortcomings in Pissarro’s paintings related to color, but also recognized the rawness and strength of the artist’s peasants, particularly in Young Peasant Having Her Coffee, stating, “However, the composure of his peasants, their poses, and manner of sitting and bending as well as their overall behavior are captured and communicated with accuracy and a striking degree of authenticity.”

Although the critics’ sentiments were mixed, the favorable reviews were indeed generally positive and encouraging. Joris-Karl Huysmans, writing in L’art moderne, was captivated by Pissarro’s depiction of the French countryside, openly rejecting his previous opinion of the artist’s works and proclaiming the artist’s departure from Millet. He effused,

On top of Mr. Pissarro’s landscapes of the Seine-et-Oise, he exhibited a whole series of peasants, and, once again, this painter shows us another side of himself and his talent! If I’m not mistaken, I once stated that Pissarro’s human figures possessed a certain biblical aura: this is no longer the case. Mr. Pissarro has completely freed himself of Millet’s influence;—He paints his peasants without any false sense of grandeur and has instead portrayed them simply, just as he saw them. All of the works in this series—from the little girls in red stockings, to his older lady wearing a headscarf, his shepherdesses and washerwomen, and even his female peasant having her breakfast or gathering grass—are true masterpieces.

In sum, characterization of Pissarro’s work in 1882 described it as a combination of Millet and Impressionist innovation. Henry Robert in La petite presse focused on Pissarro’s brilliant use of color and authentic depiction of country life, whereas Armand Sallanches in Le journal des arts also discussed Pissarro’s innovative use of color as marking a clear departure from Millet: “Mr. Pissarro’s paintings greatly resemble pastels. This artist has a preference for some of J.-F. Millet’s own subjects, but has steered clear of his use of color . . . . There is something simply stunning in his Young Peasant Having Her Coffee and his landscape Sun Setting Over Pontoise.”

Other critics saw parallels between Pissarro’s echoing of Millet and the Impressionists’ embrace of their predecessors, for example citing Jean-Babtiste-Camille Corot’s influence on Monet. As Armand Silvestre wrote in La vie moderne,

If the influence of Corot can be seen in the work of Monet, then the same can be said about Millet with regard to Pissaro [sic]. But this should not be taken as criteria for criticism. In whatever one does, there always exists lineage in terms of influence, and not so much a familial bond per se, but a spiritual bond, actually more in line with a distant relationship. This reminder of great artists should be considered a triumph in itself. I especially like the large figure paintings by Pissaro [sic] imbued with a certain rustic charm, altogether more lifelike than [Jules] Bastien-Lepage’s female peasants. I will mention here the works which are most worthy of praise, and they include: the Washerwoman, the Young Peasant Having Her Coffee, the Young Peasant Girl in a Hat, and the two large studies bearing the numbers 103 and 104. In all of these figure paintings the same sincere expression, genuine character, and humble work ethic are present. Mr. Pissaro [sic] is also a poet, not a Virgil like Corot, but profoundly deeper and more compassionate to the sufferings of those less fortunate, teeming with the same emotion that inspired Pierre Dupont to pen his painfully moving odes to rural workers, unfortunately not well known to most. Pissaro’s [sic] execution is sobering, powerful, and full of intrigue.

This extensive press coverage—less than that garnered by Caillebotte, Monet, and Renoir, but more than that earned by most of the other artists present at the 1882 Impressionist exhibition—must have heartened Pissarro in its tone and quantity, if not for its insistent reference to his debt to Millet. Pissarro was supremely conscious of being Millet’s successor as a painter of rural life, and he had spent a good deal of time in the mid-1870s wrestling with his great precursor’s example. Yet, try as he might not to borrow figures, subjects, and poses from Millet, he could not escape being interpreted in relation to his predecessor. Indeed, of all the critics cited above, only Armand Silvestre seems to have understood the fundamental differences between the work of the two artists, which lies primarily in the character and emotion of Pissarro’s figure paintings (although it must be noted that Huysmans, too, eventually concluded that Pissarro had distanced himself from Millet’s influence).

The younger artist was so exasperated by these almost automatic links of his work with Millet’s that he wrote a strong rebuttal in a letter addressed to Théodore Duret, dated March 12, 1882, during the seventh Impressionist exhibition. In it he refers to an essay by Philippe Burty. “An article by Burty was brought to my attention, one which will have a huge influence [on the way I am perceived]. He complimented me, of course—no doubt out of respect—since he was at the exhibition with [Edgar] Degas. As for the rest, all they do is compare me with Millet, but Millet was biblical! They probably make the comparison because they are particularly fond of all those artists certified as the authorities in art. Isn’t it ironic that for a Jew, one finds barely any biblical reference in my work!”

Although Armand Silvestre accurately understood the creative aspects of the filial connection between Pissarro and Millet, he linked the younger painter’s work with that of his nemesis as a painter of rural life, the talented academic painter Jules Bastien-Lepage. It was perhaps this passage that led Pissarro to think more actively about Bastien-Lepage, because the only references to him—both negative—in Pissarro’s letters are made after the 1882 exhibition. Pissarro’s figure painting was read by most critics as occupying an ambivalent position given its apparent modernity of style and the utterly traditional character of its rural imagery. Negotiating this ambivalence was to be Pissarro’s fate for the remainder of his life. Above all, what critics failed to understand was the anarchist political nature of his rural imagery, which was, to him, as “modern” as the fashionable bourgeoisie painted by Caillebotte and Renoir.

It would be hard, however, for critics to recognize this modern anarchist undertone in Pissarro’s work, precisely because he did not openly discuss it with his Impressionist peers. He spoke openly and truthfully with sympathizers such as Octave Mirbeau, his son Lucien, and those also friendly to anarchist philosophy and Marxism. The only overtly political art that Pissarro created was Social Depravities, his unpublished and privately distributed album dated December 1889.

The critics not only misunderstood the meaning of Pissarro’s imagery, but they also sometimes failed to grasp the import of his style, linking it both to the practice of pastel (a connection Pissarro would have endorsed) and to what André called “relief painting.” André’s comparison of the surfaces of the artist’s works to a geographical relief map—although probably made as a criticism—was in fact accurate and important. Complaints about their surfaces had been made since the first Impressionist exhibition, but they reached their apogee in the 1882 exhibition, when his agitated, rough, textured facture was noted by critics both friendly and unfriendly to his project.

When reviewing the artist’s first solo show in May 1883 at the Durand-Ruel gallery in the Journal des artistes, Paul Labarrière also noted Pissarro’s rough texture and unique facture, but his remarks were much harsher than André’s. Nearly all critics failed to recognize that the texture was a technique that Pissarro had developed by 1877 to introduce a wide spectrum of hues into relatively small areas of his canvases. This is most visible when looking at passages of the painting in detail (fig. 10.7), especially with the aid of a microscope (fig. 10.8). Indeed, what appears gray is, upon closer inspection, anything but, suggesting that most commentators were unable to—or did not bother to—thoroughly examine Pissarro’s pictures. Close examination reveals ruts and furrows as deep as any in the earth he painted.

The Art Institute also owns a full-scale drawing for the figure and is thus the only museum with both a large-scale preparatory drawing (see cat. 9) and the corresponding painting, which allows for side-by-side study (fig. 10.9 and fig. 10.10). Recent technical analysis has resulted in many new discoveries from which a few conclusions may be drawn. First, there is no evidence that Pissarro attempted to transfer the drawing to the canvas by squaring, pricking, or wetting the sheet (see Technical Summary in the technical report). Rather, it seems that he practiced drawing the model before moving on to the painting, getting the general outlines of the figure, the mug, the silver spoon, and the various aspects of the room in which she posed. He may have even used the drawing as a replacement for the model while creating the painting, when he had trouble either convincing her to pose again or raising the money to pay her to do so.

Yet the two works differ sufficiently for us to conclude that the drawing was made at an early stage and that Pissarro departed from it extensively—in the proportions of the figure, in the character of the room in which she sits, in the position of her hands, in the tilt of her head, in the perspective foote of her coffee cup, and in other details, such as the folds of her attire. In the drawing she appears stiff and awkward, and Pissarro seems to have been indecisive regarding her body’s proportions, perhaps altering details from memory. By contrast, in the painting it all comes off as natural, as if the viewer is in the same room, sharing a cup of morning coffee with the woman. Whereas the drawing represents what seems clearly to be the interior of a room in Pissarro’s own house, with a stand for portfolios shown to the left of the woman, the final painting omits all the particulars of the interior and focuses on the contrast between her and the window on the left side of the composition. In the painting Pissarro does add a chair so that the figure appears supported more than she does in the drawing, but it is so generic that all we can conclude about it is that it was made of unpainted wood and is very simple in design.

We do know that the Pissarro family moved in the summer of 1881, and it is certainly possible that the painting was begun in one house and completed in another. Thus, the model may have posed for more than just the drawing, yet she has never been identified. She is not Madame Pissarro or her niece “Nini” Astruc, a frequent model in 1881–83. She may be a housemaid, as Pissarro often resorted to using them as models—as, for example, in Woman Mending (1895; cat. 15). It is also possible that the heavier woman who sat for the drawing is not the same model as the one who sat for the painting, indicating that Pissarro likely had to accustom himself to making changes and possibly even relying on his memory when painting his figures.  
Richard R. Brettell

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Pissarro began this work on a standard-size, relatively fine weave, commercially primed canvas by first executing a relatively detailed, sweeping sketch in charcoal or black chalk, over which he set the major contours in fluid blue paint with a small, flat brush. He made numerous compositional changes, including major alterations to the placement of the window frame and sill, as well as changes to the figure’s hairstyle, finger placement, and profile; he also made many coloristic adjustments throughout the background. Ridges of paint seen in raking light examination reveal that many of the original compositional choices were at least partially painted before the artist changed them. In areas of pentimenti, Pissarro executed a second contour sketch directly over his initial choices before continuing to work up the composition. This is most apparent in the window frame at left. In many cases, he worked up to the edges of forms, leaving the underdrawing and ground partially exposed. The figure and background appear to have been worked up simultaneously; changes to the walls and floor at left, as well as to the general color palette in the background, appear to have been the final steps in the painting process. The work is currently unvarnished.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 10.11).

Signed and dated: C. Pissarro / 1881 (upper right, in white paint with some red) (fig. 10.12). After Pissarro signed the work, he neatened and blended the edges of the signature into the surrounding area with additional background paint (fig. 10.13).

Flax (commonly known as linen).

The original dimensions of the canvas were equal to its current size (65 × 54.5 cm) according to pretreatment measurements. This closely corresponds to a no. 15 portrait (figure) standard-size (65 × 54 cm) canvas.

Plain weave. Average thread count (standard deviation): 30.0V (0.7) × 28.2H (1.3) threads/cm. The vertical threads were determined to correspond to the warp and the horizontal threads to the weft.

The canvas has light cusping on three sides corresponding to original tack placement and strong primary cusping along the right side, seen in the warp-angle map (fig. 10.14), from commercial preparation. Close examination of the right tacking margin reveals a margin of unprimed canvas; this may be the margin of unprimed canvas along the edge of a larger section in commercial preparation (fig. 10.15).

Current stretching: The painting was lined and restretched in 1962.

Original stretching: Based on cusping visible in the X-ray and on the tacking margins, the original tacks were placed approximately 4.5–9 cm apart.

Current stretcher: Four-member ICA spring stretcher. Depth: 2.4 cm.

Previous stretcher: The pre-1962 treatment stretcher was a five-member, keyable, mortise-and-tenon stretcher with a horizontal crossbar. It is unclear if this stretcher was original to the painting. Depth: Approximately 1.6 cm.

Stamp  
Location: canvas verso (obscured by lining)  
Method: ovular stencil  
Content: COULEURS [VERNIS & TOILES A TABLEAUX] / P: APRIN / PARIS / [48] RUE DE DOUAI [48] (fig. 10.16 and fig. 10.17)

Not determined.

The ground is a relatively thin, two-layer, commercial preparation, somewhat filling the canvas weave and extending to the edges of the tacking margins. The ground is left visible in small skips in select areas of the composition, particularly the upper portion of the blue background and the figure’s skirt. The evenness of the ground, in addition to the color merchant’s stamp on the verso of the canvas, suggests the support was commercially prepared.

The ground appears warm white, with dark particles visible under stereomicroscopic examination (fig. 10.18). Visual examination of cross sections reveals the lower layer is beige with yellow, red, and black particles visible, while the upper layer is off-white with black particles visible in the matrix (fig. 10.19).

XRF analysis suggests that the ground is composed of predominantly lead white with calcium compounds, such as calcium carbonate and/or calcium sulfate, and barium sulfate. Visual examination of cross sections suggests that the iron oxide red and yellow detected by XRF is associated with the lower layer and indicated the presence of black in both the upper and lower layers. The binder is estimated to be oil.

Infrared, transmitted-infrared, and stereomicroscopic examinations indicate that Pissarro outlined the major elements of the composition in both wet and dry media. He first executed a more thorough sketch in a dry medium that included the major outlines of both the figure and background, as well as the folds in the figure’s clothing and possibly some shading in the skirt. The major contours, apparently not including the smaller folds in the sleeves and the shading, were then reinforced with a painted sketch (fig. 10.20).

Stereomicroscopic examination reveals the initial, more thorough drawing was executed in charcoal or black chalk (fig. 10.21). The artist reinforced the major elements in fluid blue paint with a small, flat brush. The blue paint served in part to fix the charcoal, and because the two media mixed on the surface, often they appear as a single medium (fig. 10.22). In some areas, the sides of the brush made firmer contact with the canvas than the center part, creating parallel lines that are in fact the edges of a single stroke (fig. 10.23).

It is unclear wether Pissarro made many changes between his initial charcoal or chalk sketch and the contour sketch in blue paint, as excess and unfixed charcoal particles were swept up into subsequent paint layers in many areas. Most compositional changes appear to have been at least partially painted before alteration. In many areas the artist appears to have executed a second contour sketch in fluid blue paint directly over previous choices, as in the windowsill and frame (fig. 10.24). For specific compositional changes see Paint Layer.

Pissarro executed this work in a number of wet-in-wet campaigns. In some cases it appears that the campaigns were allowed to dry between sessions, as in the window at left. In other areas, such as the darker blue portions of the background, traction cracking indicates that the upper layers were applied while the paint beneath was still soft, suggesting a more rapid pace of work. The artist began painting from a contour sketch, painting up to and only partially obscuring the underdrawing throughout; thus the paint along the edges of forms is generally quite thin, with the dark blue lines still visible under normal viewing conditions or under slight magnification (fig. 10.25). In some areas the exposed ground around the contours creates a kind of halo effect around objects as, for example, in the top of the spoon (fig. 10.26). Where there are compositional changes, Pissarro often returned to sketching in blue paint immediately on top of previously painted areas before continuing. In some areas the artist reinforced the amended underdrawing as a compositional device, as in the window frame at left (fig. 10.27). The work is marked by moderate impasto achieved with soft, relatively small brushes and paint of a paste-like consistency. Dabs, directional strokes, and cross-hatching were all interspersed throughout the work to generate volumetric and textural effects as the artist moved back and forth between the figure and her surroundings (fig. 10.28).

The position of the window at left is the most substantial compositional change to the work. The X-ray and infrared images indicate that the window originally took up more of the composition, jutting further to the right and down. The transmitted-infrared image confirms that the window initially extended quite low on the wall, was set at a more perpendicular angle to the frame of the painting, and continued further to the right; a faint horizontal ridge of paint corresponding to the original windowsill can be seen just under the bottom of the current sill near the left edge with a slight raking light. Stereomicroscopic examination of the surface in this area shows hints of green foliage and the muted colors of the outdoor ground underneath the current windowsill and upper portion of the wall corresponding to this earlier choice (see fig. 10.29 and fig. 10.30). Looking closely at the right part of the current window frame, greens and other landscape colors are still visible underneath it under normal viewing conditions; a faint vertical line just to the right of the white inner sill visible in infrared appears to indicate the original inner edge of the window (see fig. 10.31).

Pissarro made many small changes to the figure; transmitted-infrared reveals that he pulled her left thumb in a bit and adjusted either the lower edge of this hand or the handle of the coffee cup. The X-ray and raking-light images suggest changes to the placement of the fingers on the right hand as well, with the smallest finger originally almost touching the top of the coffee cup and the knuckles extending slightly further into the background. The X-ray also indicates that the profile features were made slightly more pronounced in the final composition. Additional changes were made to the back of the figure’s collar and possibly to the line of her upper back and the contours and placement of her ear. Pissarro appears to have changed the figure’s hairstyle the most. The bun appears much smaller in the X-ray, while the hair below it bells out further away from the neck. In the transmitted infrared image the area below the bun appears more voluminous, as if a lock of hair is hanging down or the back of the hair is more loosely gathered. In the final composition the artist bulked up the bun at the crown of the figure’s head and smoothed the silhouette of the hair between the bun and the nape of the neck with additional darker-blue background paint.

Traction cracking to the left of the figure’s forehead suggests a change in palette rather than a compositional change (fig. 10.32). A closer look at the background reveals that this area of the wall originally featured light gray-blues fading into pale, warm, earthy peach tones; hints of these original colors can be seen not only in the traction cracks but along the top edge of the composition, especially immediately above the figure’s bun. Adding darker blues both in front of and behind the figure served to separate the figure from the wall and open up the space, as well as to camouflage her original hairstyle. The artist also appears to have changed the wall below the windowsill, although the exact nature of these changes is more difficult to discern. Diagonal strokes originating from the lower edge of the original windowsill and moving from the upper left to the lower right are easily visible in raking light and appear to be a mixture of muted pale greens and tans, a warmer version of the lower layers of the background still visible at the upper right (fig. 10.33). Hints of these colors are also seen at the transition from light blue to dark-blue on the wall and at the corner just left of the figure’s right hand. At the bottom of the dark blue section of the wall, strokes parallel to the edge of the skirt in blue once continued to the top of the skirt before the tans and browns indicating the wooden floor were added (fig. 10.34). At the lower left, where the wall meets the floor, vertical strokes of red and darker blue visible along the left edge hint at possible palette or even compositional changes; separate from both the strokes of the floor and the original diagonals of the wall in this area, their original function is unknown (fig. 10.35). These coloristic alterations to the space appear to have comprised the final stages of the painting process.

Mostly small, soft-bristle, round and flat brushes with strokes up to 0.5 cm.

XRF analysis suggests the presence of the following pigments: lead white, zinc white, emerald green, vermilion, iron oxide red and/or yellow, a chrome-based pigment such as chrome yellow and/or viridian, and possibly ultramarine blue.

Stereomicroscopic examination suggests the presence of red lake throughout the composition. A sample taken from the top of the coffee mug was identified as carmine lake via SERS.

Oil (estimated).

The work is currently unvarnished. It has been cleaned and revarnished many times and retains slight residues of natural-resin varnish in the depressions of the paint layer and around areas of impasto. The earliest documented treatment in 1922 included revarnishing after removal of a natural-resin varnish, although it is unclear when that varnish was applied.

The painting’s condition was first documented in 1921, when it was recommended that it be cleaned and revarnished; this treatment was undertaken the following year. Its condition was next noted in 1953, when it was documented as showing pronounced deterioration, including a puncture above and left of center and severe wear at the corners. At this time, the painting was put on the non-lending list until it could be lined. A pretreatment exam in 1962 recorded a discolored natural resin varnish with minor overpaint, a small tear at the lower-left corner, several flake losses, slack and weak canvas, and stretcher-bar creases. Before lining the work the following year, the varnish and overpaint were removed with solvents and the canvas flattened with repeated humidity treatments. At this point the back of the canvas was also cleaned, and “uneven spots were smoothed out.” The lining process included facing the work with starch paste, followed by wax-resin lining to a new piece of linen and restretching on a redwood ICA spring stretcher. After restretching and removing the facing, the painting was given three coats of synthetic varnish (an isolating layer of polyvinyl acetate AYAA, followed by methacrylate resin L-46, retouching, and finally L-46). The synthetic varnish was found to be discolored and was removed in 2007; the work was left unvarnished.

The work is currently wax-lined, planar, and stretched on a redwood ICA spring stretcher. There are filled holes at all four corners, stretcher-bar creases along the bottom and center (from its previous five-member stretcher), and traction cracking through limited portions of the dark-blue background, including the lower wall at left and the areas immediately in front of and behind the figure’s head. The work is unvarnished with residues of discolored natural-resin varnish in the interstices and depressions of the paint layer and wheat starch paste from the lining procedure throughout; retouching appears limited to the edges.  
Kelly Keegan

Current frame (installed 1960/70): The frame is not original to the painting. It is an Italian (Bologna), seventeenth-century, Albani-style, cassetta frame. The frame has water gilding over reddish-orange bole on gesso and retains its original finish. The poplar cassetta is half lapped with applied mitered inner and outer carved poplar moldings. The back of the frame has been planed flat and a mitered basswood back frame has been glued to the verso. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, is cove; ogee–cyma recta side; cove with half bellflower ornament; reverse ogee; frieze with plain miters and centers connected by bulinatura in a pattern of guilloche with flower centers; fillet; torus with centered running laurel-leaf ornament and strapped miters; and cove sight edge. An independent fillet liner was added to adapt the frame for this painting. (fig. 10.36)

Previous frame (installed by 1933, removed at an unknown date): The painting was previously housed in a French, late-nineteenth-century, Louis XIV Revival, convex frame with deeply recessed cast plaster foliate and fleur-de-lis ornament with acanthus leaves at the miters and an independent fillet and cove liner. Although this particular frame has been lost, similar frames in the collection have water and oil gilding over red-brown bole on gesso and cast plaster. The sides and frieze are burnished, and the ornament is selectively burnished. The molding is mitered and nailed. The molding, from the perimeter to the interior, is ovolo with flower-and-dart ornament; scotia side; convex face with foliate and fleur-de-lis ornament, on a crosshatched bed, with acanthus leaves at the miters; fillet; hollow frieze; ogee with leaf-tip ornament; cove sight edge; and an independent fillet and cove liner. (fig. 10.37)  
Kirk Vuillemot

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by the artist to Durand-Ruel, Paris, Dec. 19, 1881.

Sold by Durand-Ruel, Paris, to Georges Petit, Paris, Aug. 9, 1883.

Sold by Georges Petit, Paris, to Durand-Ruel, Paris, Apr. 17, 1891, for 1,000 francs.

Sold by Durand-Ruel, Paris, to Potter Palmer, Chicago, Apr. 29, 1892, for 3,000 francs.

By descent from Potter Palmer (died 1902), Chicago, to the Palmer family.

Given by the Palmer family to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1922.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Paris, 251, rue Saint-Honoré, Salons du Panorama de Reischoffen, 7me exposition des artistes indépendants [Seventh impressionist exhibition], Mar. 1–31, 1882, cat. 111, as Jeune paysanne prenant son café.

London, Dowdeswell and Dowdeswell, Paintings, Drawings and Pastels by Members of “La Société des impressionnistes,” Apr. 20–July 1883, cat. 5, as Paysanne prenant son Café.

Sample and cross-sectional analysis using Zeiss Axioplan2 Research Microscope equipped with reflected light/UV fluorescence and a Zeiss AxioCam MRc5 digital camera. (Types of illumination used: darkfield, differential interference contrast [DIC], and UV.) In situ photomicrographs with Wild Heerbrugg M7A StereoZoom Microscope fitted with Olympus DP71 microscope digital camera.

Several spots on the painting were analyzed in situ with a Bruker/Keymaster TRACeR III-V with rhodium tube.

Zeiss Universal research microscope.

Cross sections analyzed after carbon coating with Hitachi S-3400N-II VPSEM with Oxford EDS and Hitachi solid state BSE. Analysis was performed at the Northwestern University Atomic and Nanoscale Characterization Experimental (NUANCE) Center, Electron Probe Instrumentation Center (EPIC) facility, Evanston, Ill.

A Jobin Yvon Horiba LabRAM 300 confocal Raman microscope was used, equipped with an Andor multichannel, Peltier-cooled, open-electrode charge-coupled device detector (Andor DV420-OE322; 1024×256), an Olympus BXFM open microscope frame, a holographic notch filter, and an 1,800-grooves/mm dispersive grating.

The excitation line of an air-cooled, frequency-doubled, He-Ne laser (632.8 nm) was focused through a 20× objective onto the samples, and Raman scattering was back collected through the same microscope objective. Power at the samples was kept very low (never exceeding a few mW) by a series of neutral density filters in order to avoid any thermal damage.

Thread count and weave information were determined by Thread Count Automation Project software.

Overlay images registered using a novel, image-based algorithm developed by Damon M. Conover (GW), Dr. John K. Delaney (GW, NGA), and Murray H. Loew (GW) of the School of Engineering and Applied Science, the George Washington University, and the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.

The image inventory compiles records of all known images of the artwork on file in the Conservation Department, the Imaging Department, and the Department of European Painting and Sculpture at the Art Institute of Chicago (fig. 10.47).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (PV 549; PDRS 662) corresponds to the Pissarro catalogues raisonnés: PV, vol. 1, p. 158, no. 549; vol. 2, pl. 114, no. 549; and PDRS, vol. 2, p. 442, cat. 662 (ill.). The Art Institute currently uses a title that is based on the title that was given to the painting when it was exhibited at the seventh Impressionist exhibition. The painting had the following titles during the lifetime of the artist:

Mar. 1, 1882: Jeune paysanne prenant son café (Catalogue de la 7me exposition des artistes indépendants, exh. cat. [Morris Pére et Fils, 1882], cat. 111.)  
Apr. 20, 1883: Paysanne prenant son Café. (Dowdeswell and Dowdeswell/Société des Impressionnistes, Catalogue of Paintings, Drawings and Pastels by Members of “La société des impressionnistes,” exh. cat. [Dowdeswell and Dowdeswell, 1883], p. 7, cat. 5.)  
Apr. 17, 1891: The Breakfast, Young Peasant Girl Having Café au Lait (According to Claire Durand-Ruel Snollaerts, “A Painter and His Dealer: Camille Pissarro [1830–1903],” in PDRS, vol. 2, p. 29.)  
Jan. 23, 1892: La Café au lait (Galeries Durand-Ruel, Exposition Camille Pissarro, exh. cat. [E. Ménard et Cie, 1892], p. 23, cat 16.)

For a reproduction of the manuscript for the 1882 Impressionist catalogue, see Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 377. The Art Institute also owns a pencil study for this work, entitled Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (1879/80; cat. 9).

For the caricature in Le Charivari, see Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 417. For Caillebotte’s, Pissarro’s, and Renoir’s works included in Le Charivari’s satire, see Berson, The New Painting, vol. 2, Exhibited Works, pp. 215, 226, 229, 231. Pissarro’s painting identified as Café au laid is in the middle of the satirical page, on the right side, flanked by one of Monet’s Glaïeuls and Renoir’s Young Girl Dozing. For Monet’s two Glaïeuls paintings and the Renoir works satirized, see Berson, The New Painting, vol. 2, Exhibited Works, pp. 222, 229, 231.

These included the anonymous review in L’art moderne, Paul de Chary’s review in Beaux arts, Émile Hennequin’s review in La revue littéraire et artistique, A. Hustin’s review in L’estafette, the same author’s later review in Moniteur des arts, Armand Sallanches in Le journal des arts, and Armand Silvestre in La vie moderne. For these reviews, see Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), pp. 380, 384, 393, 395, 396, 412, 413. These reviews, transcribed by Berson in French, are a great source of information on the reception of Impressionist works during their eight shows.

“Voici M. Pissarro qui se lasse de n’être qu’un paysagiste et qui entreprend de faire concurrence aux paysans de Millet. Sans doute il nous fait songer à ces paysans; mais quel profit en tire-t-il, sinon d’être écrasé par le souvenir?” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 381; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. Bigot’s review is dated March 4, 1882.

“Il faut adresser le même reproche à M. Pissaro, qui est peut-être avec M. Vignon, celui de ces artistes qui a le plus de qualités, mais qui les gâte par une exécution ‘abracadabrante.’ M. Pissaro a inventé ce qu’on pourrait appeler la peinture en relief. Ses toiles ont l’air de cartes de géographie, avec des montagnes et des vallées. Pourtant ses compositions campagnardes ont un grand charme de naïveté, et, si l’auteur consentait à quitter sa manière de faire, il se trouverait de suite occuper la place qu’il mérite.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 383; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. André’s review is dated March 7, 1882.

“Un artiste qui a réellement un grand talent comme dessinateur est M. Pisaro. Les poses de ses individus sont bien naturelles et vivantes; on sent le mouvement et la vie sous toutes ces femmes de la halle, vêtues de couleurs voyantes, et fondues ensemble dans la large buée poussiéreuse que projette un rayon de soleil.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 384; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. De Charry’s review is dated March 14, 1882.

“Mais de toutes ces erreurs, la plus singulière est celle de M. Pissarro. À force d’avoir étudié les blouses et les tabliers gros bleu des campagnards, ce dernier en est venu à apercevoir cette nuance atone partout. Ses arbres, ses prés, ses palissades, sa terre, sont peints avec ce même reflet dur, qui décolore jusqu’aux joues de ses femmes. Par contre, les attitudes de ses paysans et de ses paysannes, leur manière de se courber, de s’asseoir, de se porter, sont saisies et rendues avec une exactitude, une vérité frappante.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 393; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. Hennequin’s review is dated March 11, 1882.

“En sus de ses paysages de Seine-et-Oise, M. Pissarro exhibe toute une série de paysans et de paysannes et voilà que ce peintre se montre encore à nous sous un nouvel aspect! Comme je l’ai déjà écrit, je crois, la figure humaine revêtait souvent, dans son oeuvre, une allure biblique,—maintenant plus;—M. Pissarro s’est entièrement dégagé des souvenirs de Millet; il peint ses campagnards, sans fausse grandeur, simplement, tels qu’il les voit. Ses délicieuses fillettes en bas rouges, sa vielle femme en marmotte, ses bergères et ses laveuses, ses paysannes déjeunant ou fasant de l’herbe, sont de véritables petits chefs-d’oeuvre.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 397; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. Huysmans’s review of the Impressionist exhibition in 1882 is actually an appendix included at the very end of his 1883 publication L’art moderne (Librarie Plon), pp. 283–301. The marmotte Huysmans mentions is a type of headgear typically worn by peasants or women working in the fields, and commonly referred to as a headscarf. Huysmans’s description must refer to Pissarro’s large portrait La mère Larchevêque (PDRS 640). Several of Pissarro’s peasant women from his figure paintings between 1880 and 1883 are portrayed wearing marmottes, namely PDRS 620, 646, 658, 671, 687, 689, and 690, to name just a few. For other nineteenth-century uses of the term marmotte, see Gustave Flaubert, Bouvard et Pécuchet: Oeuvre posthume (Alphonse Lemerre, 1881), p. 31; and Émile Zola, Le ventre de Paris (Charpentier, 1873), pp. 137, 219.

“M. Pissaro se distingue de ses confrères par des qualités très personnelles. Nul ne possède mieux que lui le sentiment du calme champêtre et de la poésie des bois. . . . Les Paysannes de M. Pissaro sont des morceaux de peinture exécutés avec un conscience absolue. Ce sont là les gens de nos bois et de nos champs. Ils vivent par l’expression, par l’attitude, par la couleur.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 410. Robert’s review is dated March 5, 1882. “Les peintures de M. Pissarro ressemblent énormément à des pastels. Cet artiste recherche de préférence des sujets à la J.-F. Millet, moins la couleur . . . . Il y a quelque chose aussi dans sa ‘Jeune paysanne prenant son café’, et son paysage, ‘Soleil couchant à Pontoise’ est tout simplement étonnant.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism, 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 412; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. Sallanches’s review is dated March 3, 1882. The work called Sun Setting over Pontoise has not been identified; see Berson, The New Painting, vol. 2, p. 208.

“Si l’influence de Corot est manifeste dans l’oeuvre de M. Monet, celle de Millet ne l’est pas moins dans l’oeuvre de M. Pissaro. Et ceci n’est nullement une critique. Quoi qu’on fasse on est toujours le fils de quelqu’un. Et puis, il n’y a pas là paternité, mais simplement parenté d’âme, parenté lointaine d’ailleurs. C’est une gloire déjà, en somme, que de rappeler de grands modèles. J’aime beaucoup les grandes figures de M. Pissaro, imprégnées qu’elles sont d’un charme rustique bien autrement vrai que celui des paysannes de M. Bastien Lepage. Je citerai avec une admiration absolue, la Laveuse, la Jeune paysanne prenant son café, la Jeune paysanne au chapeau, et les deux grandes études portant les numéros 103 et 104. C’est, dans tous ces portraits, la même sincérité d’aspect, la même vérité d’attitude, la même résignation ouvrière. M. Pissaro lui aussi est un poète, non pas virgilien comme Corot, mais sombre, humain aux misères des petits, plein de ce sentiment qui inspira à Pierre Dupont un volume d’idylles vraiment trop peu connu. L’exécution de tout cela est sobre, puissante et pleine d’intérêt.” Quoted in Ruth Berson, The New Painting: Impressionism 1874–1886, vol. 1, Reviews (Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, 1996), p. 413; translation by Elpida Vouitsis, PhD candidate, University of Texas, Dallas. Silvestre’s review is dated March 11, 1882. Pierre Dupont was a French songwriter and poet born into a working-class family and affiliated in his twenties with the writers Gérard de Nerval, Théophile Gautier, and Charles Baudelaire, as well as Charles Gounod, the composer most famous for his ”Ave Maria.” Together, Dupont and Gounod composed the song ”Les Boeufs“, which made Dupont famous. Dupont was a staunch Republican, and in 1846 composed “The Workers’ Song”. In 1849, he lobbied against President (later Emperor) Napoleon III. On December 2, 1849 Dupont participated in the faubourg Saint-Antoine barricade, which—along with the publication of his compilation The Peasants’ Song in the same year—prompted his seven-year exile as a purported threat to Napoleon III.

“On me signale un article de Burty d’une glace polaire, il m’a fait des compliments étant à l’exposition avec Degas, politesse sans doute, du reste quelle peut être l’opinion d’un écrivain qui a tant de tendresse pour les hommes officiels, ils me jettent Millet à la tête, mais Millet était biblique! Pour un hébreu il me semble l’être peu, c’est curieux!” Pissarro to Duret, Pontoise, March 12, 1882, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 1, 1865–1885 (Presses Universitaires de France, 1980), p. 158. Pissarro’s letter is referring to Burty’s review dated March 8, 1882. Bailly-Herzberg’s footnote to Pissarro’s letter to Duret on March 12, 1882 suggests that he had likely not yet read Burty’s review penned a few days earlier, and that it only reached him by word of mouth, by someone obviously misinformed or exaggerating the critic’s comments. My thanks to Joachim Pissarro for his help with the translation of this passage.

Camille to Lucien Pissarro, Osny par Pontoise, June 13, 1882, and January 21, 1884, published in Janine Bailly-Herzberg, ed., Correspondance de Camille Pissarro, vol. 1, 1865–1885 (Presses Universitaires de France, 1980), pp. 218–19, 276. In the 1884 letter Pissarro reminds his son that works by Bastien-Lepage should not be considered art.

There exist several other drawings for large-scale figure paintings from 1880 and 1881, but they have never before been shown with their corresponding paintings, making it impossible to know precisely their role in the artist’s preparatory process.

Although identifying the scene seen through the window may locate the original inspiration for this work, Pissarro’s technique of juxtaposing separate color strokes to create an effect from a distance makes this task extremely difficult. It may very well be that the colors Pissarro recorded are the effect of particular light conditions and not literally those of a particular type of tree and its foliage.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the painting may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. The jagged line icon brings up a list of available annotations, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the painting’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, UV, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the painting as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper-right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper-left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

(National Gallery/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 46; and Iris Schaefer, Caroline von Saint-George, and Katja Lewerentz, Painting Light: The Hidden Techniques of the Impressionists, exh. cat. Although glue-based sizing layers are common practice in commercial preparation, no such layer was visible in stereomicroscopic examination of the painting. In addition, a thinly applied sizing layer could have been absorbed by the canvas and may not be visible under the current circumstances. Cross-sectional analysis would be needed to confirm the presence of a sizing layer.

Visual analysis of cross sections indicated the ground is a two-layer preparation. See Inge Fiedler, microanalysis results summary, May 5, 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

Visual analysis of cross sections indicates that the ground is a two-layer preparation: a lower, pigmented layer with red, yellow, and black particles visible and an off-white upper layer with black particles. See Inge Fiedler, microanalysis results summary, May 5, 2015, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

XRF analysis was carried out in air. XRF does not detect organic pigments (including carbon blacks), if present. Further analysis would be needed to confirm the presence and specific type of black. Visual analysis of cross sections indicated that the ground is a two-layer preparation: a lower, pigmented layer with red, yellow, and black particles visible and an off-white upper layer with black particles. The binding medium was not analyzed. The estimation of an oil medium is based on visual examination, as well as knowledge of Pissarro’s technique and published analyses of Pissarro’s paintings. See Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), p. 3.

A related sketch, also in the Art Institute’s collection, Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (1879/89; cat.9) provides an interesting compositional comparison to both the visible composition and earlier choices visible in the infrared and X-ray (see fig. 10.10).

Small holes present in all four corners, visible in the X-ray but now filled and inpainted, may indicate the use of spacers, or taquets bois, between painting campaigns. Possible evidence of these spacers is also seen in Pissarro’s Rabbit Warren at Pontoise, Snow (1879; cat.8), Woman and Child at the Well (1882; cat. 11), The Place du Havre, Paris (1893; cat. 13), and Woman Bathing Her Feet in a Brook (1894/95; cat. 14). For a discussion of taquets bois, see Iris Schaefer, Caroline von Saint-George and Katja Lewerentz, Painting Light: The Hidden Techniques of the Impressionists (Skira, 2008), pp. 92–93. Similar pinholes were also found on Pissarro’s The Quays at Rouen (Courtauld, 1883); see Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), p. 5.

The related preparatory sketch of the same year, Young Peasant Having Her Coffee (1879/80; see cat. 9), also shows the window lower in the composition. In the sketch, however, more of the window hardware is included and the lower part of the sill is at the same height as the figure’s eyes and nose.

XRF analysis was carried out in air. XRF does not detect organic pigments (including lake pigments and carbon blacks), if present, and has low sensitivity to elements like silicon and sodium (components of ultramarine blue). Analysis was carried out on selected areas and may not include all pigments present in the painting. For more detailed results and conditions used, see Federica Pozzi, “Psro\_CafeAuLait\_1922\_433\_XRF\_Results,” Dec. 20, 2012, on file in the Conservation Department, Art Institute of Chicago.

It is possible that this painting contains the lead white and zinc white mixture found in other Pissarro works from the 1870s and 1880s. Bomford first observed, “This [mixture of lead- and zinc-based whites] is most likely to be a paint manufacturer’s mixture: there would be no reason for Pissarro himself to combine the two pigments, and artist’s tube paints consisting of several different whites and inerts were marketed in the second half of the nineteenth century.” See David Bomford, Jo Kirby, John Leighton, and Ashok Roy, Art in the Making: Impressionism, exh. cat. (National Gallery/Yale University Press, 1990), p. 66. For a table of paintings in other collections in which this mixture was found, see Lydia Gutierrez and Aviva Burnstock, “Technical Examination of Works by Camille and Lucien Pissarro,” Art Matters: Netherlandish Technical Studies in Art 5 (2013), p. 4, table 2. Additional Pissarro paintings believed to incorporate this mixture of whites include Snow at Louveciennes (c. 1870; cat. 3), The Crystal Palace (1871; cat. 4), and Haymaking at Éragny (1892; cat. 12).

When analysis is conducted in air, XRF has low sensitivity for elements like silicon and sodium (components of ultramarine blue). The absence of cobalt or any other element associated with the blue tone in this area may indicate the use of ultramarine blue, which would not be detected under these conditions. Ultramarine blue was identified in each of the four paintings by Pissarro analyzed with SEM/EDX: The Banks of the Marne in Winter (1866; cat. 2), Snow at Louveciennes (c. 1870; cat. 3), The Crystal Palace (1871; cat. 4), and Rabbit Warren at Pontoise, Snow (1879; cat. 8).

By the early 1880s Pissarro appears to have been very much against varnishing, preferring to exhibit works under glass, as in the seventh Impressionist exhibition in 1882. Some works, such as The Village of Éragny (1885; Ashmolean Museum, Oxford), feature a typed note from Pissarro’s daughter-in-law Esther expressing both Lucien’s and Camille’s general distaste for varnish. On the verso of Landscape at Chaponval (1880; Musée d’Orsay, Paris), the artist wrote, “please do not varnish this picture / C. Pissarro”. For a discussion of Pissarro’s varnishing practices, see Michael Swicklick, “French Painting and the Use of Varnish, 1750–1900,” Conservation Research: Studies in the History of Art 41, 2 (1993) pp. 168–69. For further discussion and a reproduction of Esther Pissarro’s typed note, see Anthea Callen, “The Unvarnished Truth: Mattness, ‘Primitivism,’ and Modernity in French Painting, c. 1870–1907,” Burlington Magazine 135, 1100 (Nov. 1994), pp. 739–40.

fig. 10.5 Pierre-Auguste Renoir (French, 1841–1919). Young Woman with Cat, 1880. Oil on canvas; 120 × 92 cm (47 1/4 × 36 1/4 in.). Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts. Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Massachusetts / Bridgeman Images. This work was also satirized by Le Charivari.
